newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Tajikistan making progress in inflation battle - IMF.
newsitem.headline: Tajikistan making progress in inflation battle - IMF.

text.p: The head of an International Monetary Fund mission to Tajikistan said on Monday the remote, war-torn country bordering Afghanistan had made important progress in battling inflation.
"The rate of inflation has declined significantly," Luis Valdivieso, IMF mission chief to the former Soviet republic, told Reuters in an interview in the Tajik capital Dushanbe.
"It is significantly lower than we had anticipated in the programme," Valdivieso said.
He said lower inflation, which he predicted at around 60-65 percent for 1996, reflected a fall in prices for basic goods such as bread.
Under IMF guidance, Tajikistan planned to slash inflation to 183 percent from 2,223 percent in 1995.
The Fund lent Tajikistan $22 million in May to help stabilise the currency, the Tajik rouble, the first tranche of an $88 million credit earmarked for the republic.
"There have also been significant improvements in credit and fiscal policies and this is an important development considering the difficult general situation in the country," Valdivieso said.
Economic reform in Tajikistan has been set back by a bitter four-year civil war in which tens of thousands of people have been killed and many more displaced.
